profiledesc.creation: Text converted by SPI Content Sciences Inc., June 2003.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Documentation of the career of Texas journalist and prose writer, Leon Hale. Central to this career, since 1956, is his work as a regular "roving Texas" columnist and chronicler for the Houston Post and Houston Chronicle.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Leon Hale is a widely read and longtime columnist for the Houston Chronicle. He makes his home in Houston but spends much time at Winedale (near Round Top, TX) and Santa Fe, NM. Hale is a master at recounting tales of and reflections upon life and times in rural 20th Century Texas. He conveys all his subject's charm in the colloquial language, salty wit, and country humor that he uses so well. He is the father of Mark and Rebecca and the husband of Babette Fraser Hale.

Born May 30, 1921, at Stephenville, Texas, Leon Hale was reared in 22 different houses in nine different West Texas towns, from Fort Worth to Lubbock. His father was a store clerk and traveling salesman, but most of his relatives were farmers and his early background is entirely rural. Hale graduated from Eastland, Texas High School in 1939, entered Texas Tech at Lubbock and served 3 years in the U.S Army Air Forces before returning to "Tech" to take a journalism degree in 1946.

Hale began his journalism career as assistant editor for the Texas A&M University Extension Service, 1946-47, and progressed as follows: farm and ranch editor for the Houston Post, 1948-52; magazine editor for Humble Oil & Refining Co., 1953-55; "roving Texas columnist" for the Houston Post, 1956-1983; and since 1983, columnist for the Houston Chronicle. In addition, he has served as part-time instructor at Sam Houston State University, contributed to Texas Parade magazine, written free-lance articles, authored ten books and contributed to many others. Mr. Hale's awards include recognition by the Headliners Foundation of Texas and AP and UPI wire services. He also received the Jesse H. Jones Award for Fiction from the Texas Institute of Letters for one of his two novels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This set of papers documents Leon Hale's long and prolific writing career that began in 1946. It is divided into ten major categories with the bulk of the material being comprised of Mr. Hale's book projects, daily columns, letters from readers, and miscellaneous articles. The materials are housed in sixteen boxes, including fourteen record cartons and two oversized boxes. Each of the categories is prefaced by a detailed description.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Special Collections owns the physical items in our collections, but copyright normally belongs to the creator of the materials or their heirs. The researcher has full responsibility for determining copyright status, locating copyright holders, and abiding by current copyright laws when publishing or displaying copies of Special Collections material in print or electronic form. For more information, consult the appropriate librarian.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Leon Hale Papers, Courtesy of Special Collections, University of Houston Libraries.

scopecontent.p: The materials in this section are housed in three cartons and represent eight different volumes published by Leon Hale. The materials include correspondence with editors/publishers, business/legal documents, notes, outlines, manuscripts, typescripts, proof copies, reviews, promotions, letters from readers and even screenplays. The bulk of the material represents Hale's work on two novels, Bonney's Place and Addison.

scopecontent.p: This section includes articles and short stories, other than his regular column, authored or edited by Mr. Hale from 1946-2000. Included are manuscripts, typescripts and printed items.

did.unittitle: Annual Report, A&M Extension Service. 1 item. 1946

scopecontent.p: These folders hold pages from nine different legal pads that were filled with manuscript notations by Leon Hale. The content appears to be random, varied, and without date or formal arrangement.

did.unittitle: Working notes on ruled paper. no dates

scopecontent.p: Includes 3 different address books and 22 calendars. Only one of the address books is dated, 1976. The calendars span the years 1973-1981 and 1988-2000. The two varieties of wall calendars typically note column subjects, appointments and appearances for each day.

This set of photographs falls roughly into two categories: file or publicity shots of Mr. Hale and shots of people, places, things, and events that interested or inspired him in his work. The bulk of the photos are black and white. Those photos not of Hale appear to have been shot by him.

did.unittitle: Contact sheet, misc. images. [black & white]. no dates
Leon Hale, file photos. [black & white]. no dates
Leon Hale and other folks. [black & white]. 1966-1973
Houston Post shots, Al Shire. [black & white]. 1998

scopecontent.p: These are letters sent to Leon Hale over more than forty years. Most of them are laudatory but a few are critical. Many of them are one-time missives from loyal readers but there are as many as 145 from the most prolific of the correspondents. Some also appear to be from friends or acquaintances. Among them are letters from John Henry Faulk and Louie Welch.

did.unittitle: Letter from John Henry Faulk. 1 item. 1977
Letters from O. F. Morgan. 4 items. 1990s
Letters from R. R. Riley. 5 items. 1959
Letters from Robert C. Roach. 145 items. 1974-1994

scopecontent.p: These two scrapbooks were carefully constructed from the clipped articles authored by Leon Hale during his 1948 tenure as Houston Post, Farm and Ranch Editor.

did.unittitle: Houston Post Farm & Ranch Editor Articles

scopecontent.p: The bulk of Leon Hale's columns, printed over 54 years, will be found in this group. The acidic and crumbling newsprint clippings have been photocopied for the sake of preservation, and arranged chronologically by year. Six binders are filled with typescripts of various columns that have been thematically grouped by the author.

did.unittitle: Photocopies of Columns [clipped, sorted by month and year]
Binders of Selected Columns [grouped by Leon Hale]

scopecontent.p: There are eight wall-plaque type awards presented to Leon Hale, together with two small wooden carvings crafted by him.

did.unittitle: Wood carvings by Leon Hale. 2 items. 1942

scopecontent.p: This large group of materials is composed of items collected but not created by Leon Hale. It includes books, articles, subject files, newspaper sections, posters, work created by others, audio and video recordings. These materials were collected on the basis of their importance as information, ephemeral memorabilia or project documentation.
